awd_titl_txt: CHS: SMALL: Stress Reflection Systems in Medical Team Training
awd_abstract_narration:
Medical personnel are frequently exposed to physiological stress which can result in anxiety and other mental health issues. Indeed, stress is one of the leading causes of errors and long-term health implications for medical personnel such as emergency medical workers. Because of this, there have been efforts to introduce stress training into medical personnel training programs. If a trainee can identify, visualize, and reflect on specific events that trigger stress, performance in future situations may improve. While there has been much work focused on detecting stress from physiological response data of individuals, less work has focused on questions of how to design interventions centered around presenting stress data for an individual's comprehension, and even less so in teams and groups. This project's goal is to design, develop, and evaluate a Team Stress Reflection system, assessing its effect on stress discussions and comprehension in medical personnel team training. Societal impact will be realized through innovating new technologies that can be effectively used by medical personnel for better performance in the field, as well as supporting education and diversity through mentorship of STEM students from underrepresented groups.

The project has three main research thrusts. The first is to investigate the current stress discussion practices that occur in paramedic team-based simulation training and the impact these discussions have on stress comprehension. This will entail obtaining a detailed transcription of videos recorded during training and performing an ethnomethodologically informed, inductive data-driven analysis to find recurring patterns of interaction. A result of this thrust will be a set of user needs to inform the development of a Team Stress Reflection system and collection of a dataset of trainees' physiological responses during typical training simulations for use in evaluating the stress reflection display in the third stage of the project. The second thrust is to design and develop the Team Stress Reflection system that presents the trainees' physiological responses and situated video for individual, dyad, or team review. In the third thrust, the team will evaluate the effect of and reactions to the system on trainer-trainee stress discussion and trainee stress comprehension in paramedic team-based simulations through a series of experiments and measures comparing teams using the system to teams not using it. The results will inform the problem space of stress reflection displays as well as provide a firm basis for the feasibility and benefit of stress display intervention on medical personnel performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Presenting an individual’s verbal and nonverbal data back to them has been shown to lead to better stress awareness and reflection in high stress medical fields by improving one’s ability to handle the psychological impact of difficult work and avoid burnout. Investigation however, was needed on training interventions to support collaborative reflection to aid trainees’ stress comprehension. 

Over the five years of the project, our findings have led to deeper understanding of collaborative reflection and dyadic interactions in highly dynamic training scenarios, paramedic training specifically. We developed an interactive, educational tool that provides trainees with contextualized multimodal data from their emergency response training simulations, i.e., situated video displaying their external verbal and nonverbal behaviors, and visualizations of their physiological data displaying their internal state. To emphasize individual and team-based stress understanding, the team’s combined physiological data is presented as an area graph upon which each member’s individual data is overlaid. We evaluated the insights the trainees gained about themselves and their team's stress and dynamics through the process of collaborative reflection, the types and depths of reflection trainees achieved, and their perceived benefits and concerns of sharing physiological data in the tool. 

We learned that the presence of a partner during reflection led to more insights and deeper levels of reflection. Trainees relied equally on both the tool and their partners to interpret their stress responses and gain insights into their behaviors. They often attributed synchronization and divergence in their physiological responses to their communication and friendship outside of class. Trainees indicated little concern over privacy or ethical considerations of reviewing their physiological data with their instructors, reasoning that it would be beneficial in eliciting their empathy when evaluating trainees’ simulation performance. 

Investigating the dyadic interactions during the simulations, we found that higher levels of physiological synchrony were correlated with lower instructor-perceived stress. We also found a connection between linguistic word choice and physiological synchrony with results indicating greater use of the pronoun “we” and a higher level of affiliation when teams were in periods of high physiological synchrony. 

The results of this project are being disseminated broadly to researchers in computer science, human-computer interaction and emergency health services. The PI has incorporated the topic and findings of the research into her graduate level course on affective human computer interaction. Three graduate students, all women, have been directly supported on this project, one of whom recently defended her dissertation proposal on the topic of collaborative reflection, another who is preparing her dissertation proposal on the topic of physiological synchrony, and one who is completing her doctoral studies in Nursing Science. Several undergraduate students were also supported, many of whom have pursued graduate degrees. The anonymized electrodermal activity data is being prepared for release to the academic community.
